metadata.case_name: Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack & Anr. v. B.C. Patel & Co.

facts.text: Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Orissa Act XIV of 1947) received assent of Governor-General on April 26, 1947; s.1 came into force immediately.
Notification dated August 1, 1947, brought rest of the Act into force in Province of Orissa.
Notification dated August 14, 1947, appointed September 30, 1947, as date under s.4(1) for old Province of Orissa.
Feudatory State of Pallahara merged into Province of Orissa by covenant dated January 1, 1948.
Notification dated December 14, 1948, under s.4 Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947, extended Orissa Sales Tax Act to erstwhile feudatory States including Pallahara.
Notification dated March 1, 1949, under s.1(3), brought ss.2 to 29 into force in added territories (Orissa States).

Notification dated March 1, 1949, under s.4(1): 'In exercise of the powers conferred by Sub-section (1) of Section 4 of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Orissa Act XIV of 1947) as applied to Orissa State, the Government of Orissa are pleased to appoint the 31st March, 1949, as the date with effect from which every dealer whose gross turnover during the year ending the 31st March, 1949, exceeded Rs. 5,000 shall be liable to pay tax under the said Act on sales effected after the said date.'

Respondents (B.C. Patel & Co., partnership firm at Pallahara) assessed for sales tax for five quarters: ending Sep 30, 1949; Dec 31, 1949 (pre-Constitution); Jun 30, 1950; Sep 30, 1950; Dec 31, 1950 (post-Constitution).
Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack assessed respondents on May 31, 1951; appeals dismissed by Assistant Collector on April 12, 1952.
Respondents filed petition under Art.226 in Orissa High Court (O.J.C. No.60/1952); High Court quashed assessments on April 12, 1955.
Respondents collected Kendu leaves in Orissa, sold to merchants in Calcutta, Madras etc.; goods sent f.o.r. Talcher or Calcutta; delivered for consumption outside Orissa.
Conceded that for period April 1, 1949 to Jan 26, 1950, respondents liable if valid notification under s.4(1).
Gross turnover of respondents exceeded Rs.5,000 during year ending March 31, 1949.
Year immediately preceding commencement of Act in Pallahara: April 1, 1947 to March 31, 1948.

legal_issues.text: Whether the notification dated March 1, 1949 under s.4(1) of Orissa Sales Tax Act was valid, or severable, bringing charging provision into force for pre-Constitution assessments.
Whether respondents liable under s.4(2) for pre-Constitution periods.
Whether post-Constitution assessments valid in light of Art.286(1) and s.30(1)(a)(i) of the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification under s.4(1) validly appointed date March 31, 1949; excess part (year ending March 31, 1949) severable as surplusage.
Alternatively, pre-Constitution assessments valid under s.4(2) as gross turnover first exceeded Rs.5,000 in year ending March 31, 1949.
Post-Constitution assessments valid under Sales Tax Continuance Order 1950 and Bengal Immunity overruling United Motors on cl.2 Art.286.

respondent_arguments.text: Notification under s.4(1) invalid wholly as it specified wrong year (ending March 31, 1949 instead of preceding commencement of Act).
No liability under s.4(2) as s.4(1) would have applied if notification correct; subsections mutually exclusive.
Post-Constitution sales outside Orissa per Art.286(1) Explanation; no State power.

court_reasoning.text: Notification under s.4(1) severable: validly appoints March 31, 1949 as date; invalid part (year ending March 31, 1949) rejected as beyond power; s.4(1) determines class of dealers (turnover >Rs.5,000 year preceding Act's commencement).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Portions clearly severable; Government would have appointed date regardless.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents' concession implies turnover exceeded Rs.5,000 in year ending March 31, 1948 (preceding Act); no remand needed.
Alternatively, even if s.4(1) inapplicable, liable under s.4(2) as turnover first exceeded Rs.5,000 in year ending March 31, 1949, liability from April 1, 1949.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Subsections operate in different fields; s.4(2) requires no notification.

court_reasoning.text: Post-Constitution assessments invalid: sales outside Orissa per Art.286(1)(a) Explanation and s.30(1)(a)(i); Bengal Immunity confirms cl.1 ban independent of cl.2.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delivery for consumption outside Orissa; President's Order subject to cl.1.

holdings.text: Notification under s.4(1) partially valid after severability; pre-Constitution assessments valid.
Post-Constitution assessments without jurisdiction per Art.286(1) and s.30(1)(a)(i).

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.286(1) deems sales with delivery for consumption outside State as outside State.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Cl.1 and cl.2 of Art.286 independent bans; Explanation to cl.1 not extending to cl.2; President's Order subject to cl.1.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Charging sections; determines dealer liability based on turnover in specified years; s.30 incorporates Art.286 bans post-Constitution.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court writ jurisdiction; prohibits State tax on outside/inter-State sales.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed in part: High Court order upheld quashing post-Constitution assessments (three quarters) as invalid under Art.286(1) and s.30(1)(a)(i); reversed for pre-Constitution assessments (two quarters) as valid under valid part of s.4(1) notification or alternatively s.4(2). Parties to bear own costs in High Court and Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: "the portion of the notification which went beyond the powers conferred on the Government of Orissa is quite clearly and easily severable from that which was within its powers."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for partial validity of notification.

key_quotes.text: "the assessments for the two quarters of the pre-Constitution period were valid under sub-s. (2) of s. 4 of the Act"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the sales were outside Orissa. ... hit by cl. (1)(a) of Art. 286 as also s. 30(1)(a)(i) of the Act"
key_quotes.speaker: court
